Yes, scientists have studied the chemical reactions that occur during the cheese aging process in great detail. During cheese aging, there are various reactions that occur which can be broadly classified into physical, chemical, and microbiological processes. 

One of the most important processes that occur during cheese aging is the breakdown of proteins and fats into smaller compounds, such as amino acids and fatty acids. Enzymes produced by bacteria or fungi present in the cheese break down these components, which contribute to the flavor and aroma of the cheese.

Another process that occurs during cheese aging is the loss of moisture. As the cheese ages, it loses moisture, which results in a firmer texture and a more concentrated flavor.

Furthermore, the microbiological environment is also vital during cheese aging. Bacteria or mold cultures are intentionally added or develop spontaneously over time, interacting with the cheese proteins, and breaking them down into simpler compounds. This process also contributes to the growth of the unique and distinctive flavors in aged cheese.

In summary, the aging process of cheese is a complex and dynamic process that involves various physical, chemical, and microbiological reactions. While some of the specific mechanisms of cheese aging remain not fully understood, researchers have identified many of the chemical reactions that occur during the aging process.
